suggestion: Housing is open to all qualified applicants without regard to race.
Focus on property amenities and features rather than the neighborhood demographic.
Describe the property's location without reference to the racial composition of the area.
This property is located in an inclusive community open to all.
Describe the physical characteristics of the neighborhood.
All prospective tenants are welcome regardless of skin color.
Mention proximity to 'places of worship' generally or focus on other local amenities.
State the property is 'centrally located' or 'near various services'.
Highlight property features like 'dual sinks' or 'specialty amenities' without religious labels.
Focus on building policies like 'standard decor guidelines' or 'noise-reduced environment'.
Avoid gendered language; use terms like 'all applicants' or 'spacious layout'.
Use gender-neutral terms like 'accessory dwelling unit', 'recreation room', or 'hobby space'.
Focus on the property's suitability for 'professional lifestyle' or 'convenient living'.
Use terms like 'busy parents' or 'commuters' if targeting lifestyle, but avoid gender specifics.
Use gender-neutral occupation titles like 'server', 'flight attendant', or 'maintenance professional'.
State property features as-is (e.g., 'third-floor walk-up') without excluding specific groups.
Allow service and emotional support animals as reasonable accommodations.
Use 'conveniently located near' or provide specific distance in miles/blocks.
Reasonable modifications will be considered in accordance with the law.
Use 'equipped with ADA features' or list specific modifications (e.g., 'level entry').
Describe amenities without implying physical ability requirements.
Remove restrictions on children; describe the property's size and features instead.
Ensure the community meets HOPA requirements if intended for seniors; otherwise, avoid age-specific targeting.
State the number of bedrooms/bathrooms and let the applicant decide if it fits their family.
Suitable for anyone seeking a one-bedroom residence.
State 'near educational facilities' or 'local park proximity'.
List rooms and space (e.g., 'extra bedroom' or 'bonus space').
Do not include language requirements; provide translation services if necessary.
Focus on the property's location relative to city centers or landmarks.
Use architectural terms like 'modern', 'classical', or 'traditional'.
Ask for standard residency or identification documents required of all applicants.
Communicate effectively with all applicants.
Describe property features without age-specific language. Use 'professionals' or 'working individuals'.
If not a qualified HOPA community, remove age restrictions. If qualified, ensure proper documentation.
Student status can correlate with age. Use 'quiet environment' or 'professional setting' instead.
These terms may imply age preference. Describe specific amenities instead.
Use 'quiet neighborhood' or 'peaceful setting' without age references.
Many jurisdictions prohibit source of income discrimination. Accept all lawful sources of income.
Describe property features and amenities without economic class implications.
Focus on property suitability for 'working individuals' without job title requirements.
These terms can be code words for racial composition. Use specific street names or landmarks.
Provide objective data (crime statistics, school ratings) rather than subjective characterizations.
All qualified applicants are welcome. Remove vague exclusionary language.
These terms may imply discrimination based on familial status, religion, or sexual orientation.
Appearance-based criteria can mask protected class discrimination.
Do not reference racial quotas or balancing.
These practices are illegal. Remove all references.
Avoid language suggesting racial neighborhood changes.
Do not reference skin color in any form.
Do not discriminate based on religious beliefs or lack thereof.
Describe scheduling without religious references.
